data.title: Little Black Book
data.meta_description: THE Paris apartment that comprises the set for Jean-Claude Carrière’s Gallic hit from 1968 is so neatly arranged — suits, shirts and shoes as ordered as a clothes shop — that you just know something
data.text:
THE Paris apartment that comprises the set for Jean-Claude Carrière’s Gallic hit from 1968 is so neatly arranged — suits, shirts and shoes as ordered as a clothes shop — that you just know something is going to throw it into disarray. It duly arrives in the shape of a stranger, Suzanne, brandishing a suitcase, an aversion to work and the expectation of staying in the flat for a few days.

She soon worms her way into the life of Jean-Jacques, a bachelor lawyer and serial seducer who records his conquests — 134 to date — by recording them in his little black book (well, more of a ledger really). Over seven scenes we see this loner Lothario gradually dismantle his world as the exasperation
